Award.AwardTitle: Qualitative studies of the Navier-Stokes and related systems
Award.AbstractNarration:
The project addresses qualitative properties of solutions of the Navier-Stokes and related equations arising in fluid dynamics, including the Euler and Primitive equations. We will investigate the properties of small scales in a turbulent flow by estimating the complexity of solutions and study the relationship with the problems regarding observables and degrees of freedom in a fluid. A considerable effort will be dedicated to a fluid-structure models (local and global existence, regularity) and other complex PDE systems involving a fluid boundary. We will also study the properties solutions of the viscous and inviscid primitive equation of the ocean and the atmosphere. We will especially be interested in local and global existence of solutions and their asymptotic behavior.

The mathematical study of fluids is of fundamental importance in meteorology, science, and engineering. The project seeks better understanding of the fluid motion especially on small scales which are of interest in turbulence. The special emphasis is going to be placed on the primitive equations which constitute the basic model for weather prediction and on the fluid-structure systems modeling interaction of a fluid with an elastic body.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The purpose of the project was to obtain qualitative properties of several important modelsarising in fluid dynamics, with the main goal to consider Navier-Stokes equations, which are the principal model for evolution of a viscousfluid. However, other closely related equations were also considered, such as the Euler, Prantdl, primitive, KdV, Schrodinger, and hydrostatic equations.  The main goal of the project was to study finite time existence and blow-up, the long term behavior, and local in space smoothness behavior.


The first group of results addressed the long time behavior of the Boussinesq system. This system models evolution of an incompressible fluid with a variable density. The 2D version is also widely considered as a model for axi-symmetric solutions of the 3D Euler equations. In a series of results, we provided new information on the long time behavior of solutions. The papers show the global existencefor any H^k initial data and also provide a characterization for global solutions with L^p based Sobolev spaces.
We also considered the question of existence of solutions to the fluid equations involving free boundary. This includes the free boundary Euler equation, modeling inviscid surface waves, and the fluid-structure system, modeling an elastic body immersed in a viscous fluid. In particular, we obtained a first long time existence result for a damped fluid-structure model.
Next, we considered the inviscid limit problem, i.e., the question whether the Navier-Stokesequations with small viscosity (friction) approximate the Euler equation.  Thus we considered the long time existence of solutionsfor the Prandtl equations, which are important inthe approximation of solutions of the Navier-Stokes equations close to the boundary of the domain. We established a blow-up result for non-vanishing Euler data, showing limitations of the Prandtl asymptotics.


We also obtained results on the existence of invariant measures for dispersive equations, established certain regularity properties of the invariant measures for the stochastic Navier-Stokes equations, and proved the existence of the invariant measure for the primitive equation of the ocean.
Finally, we proved the existence of certain classes of large data leading to global solutions of the Navier-Stokes equations, obtained a new Harnack type inequalities for the parabolic equation with a divergence drift, and new existence classes for solutions of the 2D Kuramoto-Sivashinsky equation.


Intellectual merit: The purpose of the project wasto provide mathematical foundation for study ofimportant equations from mathematical fluids. We were especially interested in results whichprovide new techniques helping advancement of knowledge of properties of fluids.


Broader Impact The project involved four PhD students. Two obtained their PhD degrees while working on the project and are now postdocs at the Universities of Maryland and Nebraska. The PI has also mentored two postdoctoral associates, who also obtained tenure-track positions. The PI was active in the department with organization of seminars, along with other duties such as serving in the undergraduate and graduate committees. The PI has coorganized several mini-symposia, conferences, and workshops.

 


Last Modified: 09/23/2017
Modified by: Igor Kukavica
